text.tspan: What kind of things did you do for fun as a child?
We played soccer all the time, every day. Soccer was #1, soccer and
basketball. We’d play every day; I went to eat, do my homework and to
play soccer until it was night. We went to the movies, and going to the
movies was a big thing there. At the end, when I was in high school, we had
these American movies and music coming in, so it was a big deal to get
those movies. 80’s music was very popular. Also, every summer, we went to
the village, for summer break. We were doing everything in the village you
do now; swimming in the river, playing soccer, fishing. My grandfather took
care of a vineyard and cared for the wine—made the wine. We would harvest
the grapes in October and we would make Churchkhela [Georgian candy],
but more of them going to the clay containers to make the wine—helping
babua ["grandpa" in Georgian] with that.
What are some important traditions alone your side of the family?
We would celebrate a lot of Christian holidays, like Easter and also Supra—very
important Georgian tradition. We would spend a lot of time talking and
celebrating and making toasts with the toastmaster, eat a lot of good food,
enjoy company. We had a very important tradition of St. George’s day in
Georgia; at least 365 churches in the name of St. George. Each day for a year
there would be a small church or a big church in his name. We celebrated it on
the 23rd of November. Traditions about past relatives are important in Georgia
so you keep your relatives from time to time and remember them. Winemaking
is also a very important Georgian tradition, and they found out they have been
making wine in Georgia for 8,000 years. There were 300 different varieties of
white and red grapes which only grow in Georgia.
